title: Fatigue and Balance Issues in a Patient with Multiple Sclerosis
clinical_history: A 35-year-old female, diagnosed with relapsing-remitting Multiple Sclerosis (MS) 5 years ago, presents with complaints of fatigue, balance issues, and weakness in her lower extremities. She reports that her symptoms worsen throughout the day, especially after engaging in physical activities. She has experienced 3 relapses in the past 5 years, with the most recent one occurring 6 months ago, resulting in numbness and weakness in her left leg. She is currently able to ambulate with the assistance of a cane.

nprs.affected_area: sharp pain and numbness in left leg

aggrevating_factors: prolonged physical activity, hot weather, stress
picture: a person with a cane, highlighting the lower extremities
past_history: The patient has a history of optic neuritis in her right eye 7 years ago, which resolved spontaneously. She has also experienced occasional episodes of numbness and tingling in her hands and feet.
medical_history: The patient is currently taking disease-modifying therapy (DMT) for her MS, and has a history of hypothyroidism, well-controlled with medication.
medications: Glatiramer acetate (Copaxone) 20mg SC daily, levothyroxine 50mcg PO daily
personal_history: The patient is married with two children, ages 7 and 9. She works part-time as a librarian and enjoys reading and hiking in her free time. She reports that her MS diagnosis has had a significant impact on her daily life, causing her to limit her activities and rely more heavily on her support system.
imaging: MRI of the brain and spinal cord, showing multiple white matter lesions consistent with MS
